Possibly there may have been a harshness in Grosseteste’s manner or mode of proceeding, though certainly no sign of this is visible in the letters he wrote to them. Indeed, the very curious and lengthy argumentative letter (or rather pamphlet) which he addressed to them on the subject is a very remarkable evidence to the contrary, its tone being most moderate throughout. It is a very singular specimen of the mode of thought of the time. And if 1116 arguments seem weak and fanciful to us now, it should be remembered that not only are they such as appeared weighty to Grosseteste, but also such as he expected would influence the chapter, and thus give a curious insight into the mediaeval mind.
